body: I know what the problem is. Fix incoming.
Pushed 3.3.2 to fix. Sorry about that!

issue.title: SCRIPT438: Object doesn't support property or method 'transition'  d3.js, line 8600 character 5

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
Hi Mike, 
I'm trying to upgrade d3.js from version '3.3.13' to '3.5.2'.
I ran into the issue as described in issue title.
It only happens in IE browser.
It pretty much the same issue as https://github.com/mbostock/d3/issues/1491, but i don't think it is fixed already.
Do you have any suggestion on this?

Thanks in advance!

Ramsey

body: I am still seeing the Object doesn't support property or method 'transition' d3.js error after installing 3.3.2

I've been reproducing this bug with `3.5.3`. In IE 9 and IE 10. 
If I switch to version `3.5.0` the error disappears. 

I think the issue could be here:
https://github.com/mbostock/d3/commit/ee0e2d7ad6bc3ff3eaf7e07fdd14e1b305895084

Yes, I can reproduce this problem (IE9, v3.5.3): Object doesn't support property or method 'transition', d3.js line 8600.
Would it be possible to reopen this issue?

Reproduced.  The problem is that IE9 doesn’t support prototype injection, so we use direct extension instead.  However, this assumes that all methods are already on the prototype object at the time of subclassing, which unfortunately is not the case for `d3_selectionRoot` as it is defined at the end of `selection/selection.js`, which is expanded before `selection/transition.js`.

There is a similar problem for `d3_selectionPrototype.on` and `d3_selectionPrototype.interrupt`, which are declared after `d3_selectionRoot` is defined, if you look at the SMASHed file.

Perhaps `d3.selection` should be modified to use lazy initialisation, rather than eagerly initialising `d3_selectionRoot`.  Patch here: #2223.

issue.title: Demote JSDOM to development dependency.

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
Fixes #2190 #1491 #2180 #1986 #1250.

Code that previously assumed a global document or window now uses the related node’s ownerDocument or ownerDocument.defaultView as appropriate.

If no related node is available, the corresponding code will crash; however, the rest of D3 will work just fine. For example, you can’t use d3.select(string) unless a global document is available; it just doesn’t make sense. Use d3.select(node) instead, followed by selection.select(string).

Code that previously checked for a global on the window (e.g., XDomainRequest) now uses the global context (`this`) rather than the window.

issue.title: d3.transition() crash in IE<11

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
When using D3 with C3.js in IE10 or lower, C3 makes a call to d3.transition() without any arguments, and this crashes in IE10 and lower because d3_selectionRoot has no transition method defined.  This in turn is because d3_subclass fakes inheritance in IE<11 where there is no **proto** property by doing:
for (var property in prototype) object[property] = prototype[property];  at the time that d3_selectionRoot is created.  Unfortunately, at the time d3_selectionRoot is created, d3_selectionPrototype does not yet have the transition method defined.  If you move   d3_selectionRoot = d3.select(d3_documentElement);
to after all the d3_selectionPrototype stuff is setup at line 8573, the problem is solved. 

Is this a real issue, or am I or C3.js simply using D3 wrongly?
